case_vignette:
A 4-year-old boy is brought in for a routine checkup. His father says that the boy bruises quite easily and he is worried about his son’s height. The boy was born at 39 weeks gestation via spontaneous vaginal delivery. He is up to date on all vaccines and is meeting all developmental milestones. On physical examination, he is in the 10th percentile for height and 30th for his weight. Examination of his abdomen reveals hepatosplenomegaly. His liver function test results are normal. A complete blood count shows the following:
Hemoglobin: 9.1 g/dL
Hematocrit: 28.4%
White cell count: 8,400/mm3
Platelets: 15 x 109/mm3
A bone marrow biopsy shows mildly hypocellular marrows with diffuse macrophages with eosinophilic cytoplasm. The cytoplasm looks like wrinkled tissue paper on further inspection. No blasts are observed.
question: Which  is the next best step in confirming the diagnosis of this patient’s condition?
correct_ans: measurement of glucocerebrosidase activity in peripheral leukocytes
